Panetta hints of punishment for bin Laden book author

Defense Secretary Leon Panetta is suggesting a retired Navy SEAL be punished for writing a book detailing the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. (AP, 8:17 a.m.)

206 Mass. 9/11 victims remembered

In events at the State House and Boston Public Garden, public officials and citizens commemorated the 206 local victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. (Globe, 10:31 a.m.)

Opinions among the state's faiths vary widely on an issue that proponents refer to as “death with dignity” and opponents call “doctor-assisted suicide.” (Globe)

Why go to high school reunions?

The stubborn, almost irrational allegiance to the place where you were born seems coded into nature itself.

Work of Harvard’s Faust makes PBS

Along with filmmaker Ric Burns, Harvard president Drew Gilpin Faust will travel the East Coast to promote a new two-hour film, “Death and the Civil War.”

State GOP takes up national platform

Mass. Republicans are scheduled to vote on whether to replace their issues platform with the controversial version embraced at the RNC.

Storming ahead with Bob Dylan

Coinciding with the 50th anniversary of his self-titled debut, Bob Dylan’s "Tempest" is a ragged collection of songs fixated on death and depravity.
Opinion | Joanna Weiss

A teacher’s guide to predators

The new manual for schools underscores a disturbing but intuitive concept: In order to gain access to kids, sexual abusers have to manipulate adults.

Mattapan welcomes health center

The new $34 million home for the Mattapan Community Health Center will double the number of patients the facility serves, officials said.
